node.bodyText:

node.title: A 2D mesh with circular region, and applying a constant force on the circle
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am trying to analyze the problem in the image attached. Please how do I get a rectangular mesh with a circular region? And how do I apply a constant forcing term on the circular part? Thank you.

Hello
For the constant forcing term, I think you will want to have a look at using a boundary condition if the variables only outside the circle in the rectangular regions.
To obtain a rectangular mesh with a circular hole, I think we have an example here:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/navier_stokes/examples/flow-over-circle/mesh.i
Guillaume
Thank you

Hi,
I can recommed to use Gmsh for meshing the domian.
you can create rectangular mesh with a circular region in.
If you want to apply boundary condition on the circle,  you can define the circle as a physical property then you will have access to that in MOOSE input file.
Thank you!
Using a circular body force specified over the region of interest also works

node.title: VectorPostprocessor output as a boundary condition
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Please how can I use a Vectorpostprocessor such as the LineValueSampler and SideValueSampler as a Boundary condition without having to output in a csv file. This is because the values in the vectorpostprocessor change at every iteration and I need to update the changed values as new BC at each time step.
Thank you!

Hello
Are you using a MultiApp?
Or is the coupling between the two equations (one that computes the VPP, and one that uses) within in the same input file?
Guillaume

I am using MultiApp with two input files.
The two files compute the VPP separately, and each of them uses the scaled VPP values coming from the other as BC.

ok you can transfer the VPP directly between the two applications using this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/transfers/MultiAppVectorPostprocessorTransfer.html
Alright. Thank you.

I got this error:

This is quite understandable since I only have one subdomain.
To be more clear in my problem:

I want to transfer across the interface using two different input meshes. The VectorPostprocessor only allows me to transfer a scalar value to multiple subdomains at the same time. But, I want to transfer vector of values at the boundary to the other domain. MatchedNode did not quite give me the expected values too.

hello
my bad I got this wrong
You have to use this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/transfers/MultiAppReporterTransfer.html#vector_transfer
Guillaume

Thank you
I was able to effectively transfer using NearestNode and coupled BC

node.title: Unable to run phase-field fracture simulations using spectral decomposition of strain energy
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I've created a model for a single edge notched tension test loaded in displacement control in moose using phase-field coupled with tensor mechanics and a volumetric deviatoric decomposition of strain energy. However, when I try to change the decomposition type to "spectral", the solver always fails to converge at the early steps of the simulation. I've already tried to use different petsc options, mesh, displacement increment, nothing works. I'm also running 2 versions: monolithic and staggered schemes (one single app and using multiapp). I'm sending attached the monolithic version that works with volumetric deviatoric.
Does anyone have any tips on how to get this to work with spectral decomposition? Thank you!
sent.zip
Hi, thanks for reporting this. Could you convert this into an issue? I will look into this.

Hello moose developers,
I am new moose user and interested in developing models for phase field fracture in polycrystals. I have been trying to reproduce
pure shear tests published in many articles using spectral decomposition. First I considered newton method and figured out that there was an issue because of the jacobian so I implemented a new jacobian based on the projector of the strain_old  (or stress_old) which is normally stable. However even with this I could not have convergence. Could anyone help us in solving this ?
Thank you in advance.

Hello moose developers,
I am new moose user and interested in developing models for phase field fracture in polycrystals. I have been trying to reproduce
pure shear tests published in many articles using spectral decomposition. First I considered newton method and figured out that there was an issue because of the jacobian so I implemented a new jacobian based on the projector of the strain_old  (or stress_old) which is normally stable. However even with this I could not have convergence. Could anyone help us in solving this ?
Thank you in advance.

What was the issue with the oringal code?  The Jabobian should be correct.

Thanks for your reply.
The jacobian is correct, but we think that the spectral method would not converge with a  vacillating Jacobian due to a null eigen value in a pure shear test.  That is why we have considered the "old" Projector instead of the current when computing the Jacobian, and even with this, we could not have convergence.
regards,

Hello
You should test the jacobian using our automatic tools to determine that
See this page:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/development/analyze_jacobian.html
Guillaume

Thanks for your reply.
The jacobian is correct, but we think that the spectral method would not converge with a vacillating Jacobian due to a null eigen value in a pure shear test. That is why we have considered the "old" Projector instead of the current when computing the Jacobian, and even with this, we could not have convergence.
regards,

I do not remember we have much convergence trouble with the pure shear test. Does it converge badly on linear or nonlinear iterations?
Could you paste your "executioner" block here?

We have tried many execution scenarios, the last one is :
[Executioner]
[./TimeStepper]
type = IterationAdaptiveDT
dt =1.0e-8  # Initial time step.  In this simulation it changes.
optimal_iterations = 8 # Time step will adapt to maintain this number of nonlinear iterations
growth_factor = 1.5
[../]
type = Transient
#solve_type =newton #PJFNK
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package -snes_type'
petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                  vinewtonrsls'
automatic_scaling = true
line_search = 'none'
nl_rel_tol = 1e-3
l_tol = 1.0e-4
l_max_its = 200
nl_max_its = 14
dtmax = 3.0e-2
dtmin = 1e-11
end_time = 20.0
[]

See this app as an example: https://github.com/hugary1995/raccoon/tree/devel/tutorials/mode2_brittle_fracture

The jacobian is correct, but we think that the spectral method would not converge with a vacillating Jacobian due to a null eigen value in a pure shear test.

I also don't quite understand this statement.

Of course I did not face problems with non pre-cracked meshs. However with a pre-cracked one, like in many articles, it never converged. The pre-crack could be either d=1 or a real mesh cut.
regards

However with a pre-cracked one, like in many articles, it never converged.

But many articles show results generated with MOOSE...
That is why we are asking how these results have been obtained

disp_y = 0 everywhere on the external boundaries: left,right, top and
bottom.

Le jeu. 23 févr. 2023 à 19:37, Gary (Tianchen) Hu ***@***.***>
a écrit :
…
 Great, we are getting somewhere :)

 So I may have totally misunderstood your "pure shear" test. By "disp_y has
 to be zero everywhere", do you mean you also want to set disp_y on the left
 and right boundaries, or do you mean you literally want to set disp_y
 *everywhere* on the domain, i.e., on all the nodes?

node.title: Unrealistic results in 3D simulation
node.bodyText:
I got a weird result in a 3D simulation. The sample is a common notched round bar. The displacement at the top is 0.3*t and the bottom is fixed as shown in the attached figures. But weirdly the maximum von Mises stress is at the top not at the bottom as expected.



My input file is as follwing:
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Mesh]
    [base]
        type = FileMeshGenerator
        file = NRB_R2_complete.inp
    []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [./all]
    strain = FINITE
    add_variables = true
    generate_output = 'max_principal_stress triaxiality_stress vonmises_stress plastic_strain_xx plastic_strain_yy plastic_strain_zz'
  [../]
[]

[Functions]
  [./hf]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    data_file = stress_data.csv
    format = columns
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./y_pull_function]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = top
    function = 0.3*t
  [../]
  [./y_bot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0.0
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 2e5#MPa
    poissons_ratio = 0.29
  [../]
  [./isotropic_plasticity]
    type = IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate
    yield_stress = 431.46 #MPa
    hardening_function = hf
  [../]
  [./radial_return_stress]

    inelastic_models = 'isotropic_plasticity'
  [../]
  [lode_angle]
    type = ComputeLodeAngle
    outputs = exodus
  []
  [critical_crack_strain]
    type = ComputeCriticalCrackStrain
    outputs = exodus
  []
  [peeq]
    type = ComputePEEQ
    outputs = exodus
  []
  [d]
    type = ComputeDamage
    alpha = 1.0
    beta = 1.0
    critical_fracture_stress = 1204
    outputs = exodus
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'

  petsc_options = '-snes_ksp_ew'
  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart'

  line_search = 'none'

  l_max_its = 50
  nl_max_its = 50

  print_perf_log = true
[]

nl_abs_tol = 1e-6
this is pretty coarse. Let's tighten it and/or add automatic_scaling  to make sure we're looking at converged results
Guillaume
Ok, thanks. I will try it.
I change  nl_rel_tol = 1e-10, nl_abs_tol = 1e-12. The maximum von mises stress is still at the top...

2e5#MPa how did you change the units here?
I think this should be in Pa

I didn't pay attention to the units yet. I want to see how can I incorporate the hardening law into the simulation. So I used the same data as that in an Abaqus simulation, the young modulus is 200GPa=2e5MPa.

=2e11 Pa.
Super low young modulus in the simulation would impact the results

Hello, I changed the young's modulus to 2e11, the result was still the same. Then I used a simple cylinder model to test with same BCs and material properties, and simply used ComputeLinearElasticStress, the maximum von mises stress is still at the top.
@recuero you may want to check this thread too for context

But weirdly the maximum von Mises stress is at the top not at the bottom as expected.

If you are modeling cracking, the areas with large stresses will suddenly have zero stress. In that case, your results wouldn't look too bad depending on what you are modeling.
When you say you simply used ComputeLinearElasticStress: Is that all you used? Or you also accounted for damage?
I agree with @recuero this is due to your damage model.

But weirdly the maximum von Mises stress is at the top not at the bottom as expected.

If you are modeling cracking, the areas with large stresses will suddenly have zero stress. In that case, your results wouldn't look too bad depending on what you are modeling.
When you say you simply used ComputeLinearElasticStress: Is that all you used? Or you also accounted for damage?

Yes this is all what I used. To test I disabled damage computation during the simulation, but the maximum stress is still at the top.

Hello
So to convert directly an auxvariable to a material property you can use the ParsedMaterial:
[./phasemap]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    f_name = matprop_name_you_want
    args = 'variable_name'
    function = 'variable_name'
[../]

Hi
So I see a few problems with these inputs.
Both solves are on the same mesh, which lets me think that you do not want to be using a variable value sample transfer. This is to take the variable value at a point in the mesh, and create a simulation that is local to that point. For a multiscale approach basically.
I think you want to be using a MultiAppCopyTrasnfer, to transfer the full field from one app to the other.
Then disp_x, c are primary variables in both applications. You cant transfer to primary variables, since these are the variables you are solving for. You need to trasnfer to an auxiliary variable with a different name, then use it as an initial condition for the primary variable. Or at least that's what I think you should do, but it really depends on what your coupling scheme is.
hold that thought, I need to check on this

Transfer the material property (elastic_energy) through a AuxVariable is not a good idea. It needs first to project the material property to the nodes and then interpolate it back to quadrature points. This will cause accuracy issue. In addition, you should not use CONSTANT MONOMIAL for elastic_energy because that averages the material property as a single value. I am not sure quite sure if the FIRST MONOMIAL would work or not, but you can give it a shot. You can output material property by adding outputs = exodus to visualize them in paraview. Take a look at if you get nonzero elastic energy in the sub app.
I suggest you transfer displacement variables and recompute the elastic energy in the fracture app. We have been using that for the staggered approach. A better approach is to transfer the material property directly, but as you already discovered, that is not supported yet.
Lastly, you need to add Picard iteration to ensure your solution converges for each time step.

@asingh-mit You can use these inputs as a reference for setting up your model in moose in a staggered way: https://github.com/hugary1995/raccoon/tree/master/tutorials/mode1_brittle_fracture
@jiangwen84 is right about the accuracy issue using constant monomials for transferring elastic energy. However, that error is usually quite acceptable in practice in my experience.

"I suggest you transfer displacement variables and recompute the elastic energy in the fracture app. We have been using that for the staggered approach. A better approach is to transfer the material property directly, but as you already discovered, that is not supported yet."

it doesnt cache by default and I dont see it in the parameters of the action. So I think you ll have to modify the code a little bit to get this to work.
add the caching parameters in the code for the action, when it creates the study, right below this line.

  
    
      moose/modules/heat_conduction/src/actions/RadiationTransferAction.C
    
    
         Line 233
      in
      935a1fe
    
  
  
    

        
          
           InputParameters params = _factory.getValidParams("ViewFactorRayStudy");
Hmm, I'm a little green so a little more assistance for how to proceed would be awesome.  But let me give this a shot.  After modifying the code, I would need to re-make moose, right?

Yup you need to make every time you modify the code.
It should only rebuild a few files at most though (unless you touch a header).
No need to add a parameter to the RadiationTransferAction, just hard-code a true to caching segments for now
Oh my gosh I think it's working.  Wow.  Code still running- apparently that caching is a lot.  Here's the line I added:
Further question: when I view the exodus output, I don't see any rays reflecting off the surfaces.  I only see them emanating from the patches.  Here is a screenshot:
Am I doing something wrong?  Shouldn't these rays be reflecting off the vacuum walls based on emissivity and absorption?

I did a little more digging and I just want to confirm my understanding of the GrayDiffuseRadiation action:
It seems like Moose calculates radiative heat transfer based on material properties and view angles between the surfaces.  The patches emit rays using gaussian quadrature.
However, this model seems like it may break down with highly reflective surfaces like polished aluminum.  If the surface is highly reflective, then shouldn't the patches be modeled based on the angle of incident rays?  In that case, I would expect the radiative heat transfer to be calculated from rays reflected multiple times, rather than having each ray die at its first intersection with a boundary.
Does this make sense?  If so, is there a way to allow RadiationTransferAction to reflect rays a few times before killing them?

@loganharbour or @snschune may complement this
I dont think it would break down. The idea here is to get the view factors between the patches on both sides, then perform the linear (nonlinear with T dependent properties) solve to converge the radiation heat exchange. The reflectivity is naturally baked into the amount of energy communicated between surfaces, as a factor on how much energy gets sent back.
The rays are fixed, they are simply here to compute view factors.
The idea is not to track rays of light dynamically between the two surfaces until they dissipate.

Okay, interesting! Do you have some references that go a little deeper. I still don't fully understand. Specifically, I don't understand how this method accounts for specular reflection. It seems to assume only diffuse reflection.
I ll refer to the aforementioned developers for this

The net radiation transfer method that is implemented is a fairly standard approach to gray (no frequency dependence), diffuse (all boundaries emit & reflect like Lambert radiators). The case of polished Al would be better described by specular reflection which net radiation transfer typically excludes. The difference is that of a white and specular reflected boundary in radiation transport. Note that most engineering surfaces are some mixture of the two.
To the question about view factors and rays. @GiudGiud already explained it but I want to add one thing. View factors are essentially first flight surface to surface collision probabilities from the collision probability method in radiation transport. The probability that a photon released in direction Omega makes its first contact with surface patch j. The radiative exchange is can be computed from these first flight exchange probabilities by a little bit of book-keeping and math. That is essentially what @GiudGiud described.
That bookkeeping includes diffuse reflection, absorption, and radiation. That is why rays are killed at first contact with the next surface...it's because we only want first flight surface-to-surface collision probabilities.
NOTE: the full problem with specular reflection, energy dependence, and absorption in any media within the cavity can also be solved using the MOOSE based radiation transport application Griffin.

node.title: Tensor Material Component Notation
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I was using GenericFunctionRankTwoTensor, and outputting the results to an Exodus II file. I noticed that the component indexing specified in the docs ('fcn_00 fcn_01 fcn_02 fcn_10 fcn_11 fcn_12 fcn_20 fcn_21 fcn_22') were flipped when output to the Exodus file (i.e. the same components were named 'fcn_00 fcn_10 fcn_20 fcn_01 fcn_11 fcn_21 fcn_02 fcn_12 fcn_22' in the output).
Lines 219:228 of RankTwoTensorImplementation.h indicate the tensor is filled in a column-major fashion (i.e. the order I experienced in the output exodus), which is opposite to the docs for GenericFunctionRankTwoTensor.
I did put together a MWE (below) to demonstrate this using GenericConstantRankTwoTensor, which shows if you input the components in a row-major order they get flipped as expected. Is this just a mistake in the docs or am I missing something?
Thanks

tensor.i
[Mesh]
  [mesh]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [var]
    initial_condition = 0
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [dmdt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = var
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [const]
    type = GenericConstantRankTwoTensor
    tensor_name = const
    tensor_values = '00 01 02 10 11 12 20 21 22'
    outputs = exodus
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  dt = 1
  end_time = 1
[]

[Outputs]

node.title: Plasticity Hardening Model
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm working on precipitation hardening of aluminum alloys and have already written source code to assess microstructure development and yield stress. I'm now attempting to adapt the IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate.C and IsotropicPowerLawHardeningStressUpdate.C source codes to utilize a new hardening model in plastic deformation based on the equations below.

Do you know how I may update the IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate.C and IsotropicPowerLawHardeningStressUpdate.C source codes or build a new one to adopt this hardening model?
Sincerely,
Sajjad
You should write a new material for this. IsotropicPowerLawHardeningStressUpdate is a decent example.

node.title: Convergence problem solving Current continuity Eq. by MatDiffusion kernel
node.bodyText:
Hello, guys.
I tried to solve Poisson's equation (Current continuity) by MatDiffusion kernel and found a convergence problem.
Physical system (that I want to implement) Description:
I want to investigate the evolution of defects which is electrically conductive and electric current from x=0 to x= 10 (nm).
The way of generating defect is changing the eta value from 0 to 1 and this contributes to electrical_conductivity.
Each mesh defines both Pc and P, and Pc increases when the electric field evaluated in the mesh increases.
The defect is generated when the nucleus-generating probability (Pc) is higher than 0.1 (P).
The execution type is time-transient.
No time-derivative term is in Poisson's equation but I increase x=0 BC from 4.0V to 4.8V (voltage) in 200-time steps, that's why.
I want to know how I am able to successfully do this calculation.
My input file:
####### time step #######
TIME_STEP = 0.05
steps = 200
####### time step #######

######## Mesh ########
xmax = 10
ymax = 20
xdelta = 0.2
ydelta = 0.2
nx = ${fparse ${xmax} / ${xdelta} }
ny = ${fparse ${ymax} / ${ydelta} }

##### Voltage ######

##### Voltage ######

  ymin = 0
  ymax = ${ymax}

[]

    format = columns
    scale_factor = 1.0

[]

  [../]
[]

  ######## Additional END #####
[]

[AuxKernels]
  ######## Electric #######

    type = PotentialToFieldAux
    variable = Ex
    gradient_variable = V
    sign = negative
    component = x
  []
  [Ey_aux]
    type = PotentialToFieldAux
    variable = Ey
    gradient_variable = V

    component = y
  []
  [current_density]
    type = CurrentDensity
    variable = J
    potential = V

    vector_variable = J
    component = x

  ######## Additional #########

    type = ParsedAux

  #  petsc_options_value = 'asm        101                 preonly         ilu             1'
  l_tol = 1e-8 # linear tolerance
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8 # nonlinear relative tolerance
  nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-9 # nonlinear absolute tolerance
  automatic_scaling = true # for line search convergence
  l_max_its = 100 # linear max iterations
  nl_max_its = 40 # nonlinear max iterations
  [./TimeStepper]
    type = SolutionTimeAdaptiveDT
    dt = ${TIME_STEP}
  [../]
  dtmin = ${fparse ${TIME_STEP}/5000000}
  num_steps = ${steps}
[]

[Postprocessors]
  ######## Electric #######
  [./Resistance]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    function = 'if(Current<1e1,${Voltage}/Current,0.0)'
    pp_names = Current
  [../]
  [average_Jx]
    type = SideAverageValue
    variable = Jx
    boundary = right
  []
  [Current]

[]

[Debug]

[]

[Outputs]

Hello
There's a few red flags in the convergence history
     29 Linear |R| = ^[[33m1.216652e-10^[[39m
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_BREAKDOWN iterations 30

while we are solving seemingly fairly tightly, the result is being rejected.
This probably means the convergence criteria need to be adapted.
You can also scale the convergence criteria using automatic scaling to make it more normalized.
You ll want to look at the parameters to set this in the Executioner.
Once you get convergence on all steps, you can consider whether the results are correct
Guillaume
